attributes.title: Open source, low cost, respirator - COVID19 Concept
attributes.description: It is an open source design concept for a low cost mechanical respirator based on manual resuscitator or "self-inflating bag", which is a hand-held device (130 mm diameter) commonly used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients who are not breathing adequately). The hardware consists of 3D a design concept based on a low-cost, high-torque motor, designed for car window lifter. This design has minimal quantity of moving pieces while allow the design of adequate air flow and pressure mechanically, without the need of digital control.

attributes.title: Survey Experiments on Stigma and Narratives
attributes.description: This study seeks to examine the role of narratives in mitigating the effects of a stigma, specifically the stigma of a criminal record in the search for employment. Prior research has examined the ways that narratives impact the experience of stigma for the identity construction of the stigmatized individual and have theorized that narratives have the potential to mitigate stigma in how others treat the individual with the stigmatized status. Yet no research of which we are aware has tested such a stigma mitigation hypothesis in the context of criminal record stigma in the labor market. This study will test this hypothesis by presenting survey respondents recruited through Amazon MTurk with the task of evaluating a fictitious job applicant for a fictitious job. We will randomly assign survey respondents to either a job applicant without a criminal record or one of several job applicants with criminal records who present different narratives about their lives since they acquired the record. The goal is to test the hypothesis that job applicants with different narratives about their criminal record and subsequent lives will experience different stigma from the criminal record (as measured by different evaluations by the survey respondents).

q1.value: Survey Experiments on Stigma and Narratives

q2.value: David Harding, Maria smith, Da Eun Jung

q3.value: This study seeks to examine the role of narratives in mitigating the effects of a stigma, specifically the stigma of a criminal record in the search for employment. Prior research has examined the ways that narratives impact the experience of stigma for the identity construction of the stigmatized individual and have theorized that narratives have the potential to mitigate stigma in how others treat the individual with the stigmatized status. Yet no research of which we are aware has tested such a stigma mitigation hypothesis in the context of criminal record stigma in the labor market. This study will test this hypothesis by presenting survey respondents recruited through Amazon MTurk with the task of evaluating a fictitious job applicant for a fictitious job. We will randomly assign survey respondents to either a job applicant without a criminal record or one of several job applicants with criminal records who present different narratives about their lives since they acquired the record. The goal is to test the hypothesis that job applicants with different narratives about their criminal record and subsequent lives will experience different stigma from the criminal record (as measured by different evaluations by the survey respondents).

q4.value: Considering what we know about the relationship between employment and incarceration, we expect more people to choose the no criminal record job candidate [Jonathan Smith] over the record-holding job candidate [Christopher Williams]. Understanding this, our research is aimed at understanding the degree to which particular narratives lessen the stigma of incarceration in the labor market. From greatest to least mitigating, we expect the Textbook Addiction, Bad Influence, Economic Motivation, and No Narrative cover letter narrative to do better than the Wrong by the System cover letter narrative.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: Neither the respondent nor the researcher will know which treatment is assigned during the study.  The researcher will become aware once the data is analyzed.

question.value: The study team will post a Human Intelligence Task (HIT) on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Respondents will then be directed to a Qualtrics survey. The first screen of the survey will show the consent form. The consent form will describe the purpose of the study as learning about how job applicants are evaluated. Respondents will then take the survey. The survey includes reading a short passage that describes the main task (evaluating two fictitious job candidates for a fictitious customer service job at an unnamed large retailer) and then reading the resumes and cover letters for two fictitious job applicants. All respondents will see the same resumes, but they will be randomized to see different cover letters for the fictitious candidate with a criminal record. One fictitious applicant will be an individual without a criminal record. The other will be for an individual with a criminal record and research subjects will be randomly assigned to cover letters with different narratives about the criminal record and what has happened to them since. In addition, among the five cover letters, one will indicate they have a criminal record but no narrative will be provided to determine if the narrative is meaningful. The survey will then include a series of questions that evaluate the job candidates, attention checks, and demographic, criminal record, and work history of the respondent, specifically whether or not the respondent has ever worked in human resources or retail. They will also include attitude questions about social policy generally and about criminal justice policy specifically.

q9.value: All respondents will see the same resumes but they will be randomized to see different cover letters. One fictitious applicant will be an individual without a criminal record. The other will be for an individual with a criminal record and research subjects will be randomly assigned to cover letters with different narratives about the criminal record and what has happened to them since.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: Prior to registering the project and collecting the targeted sample size data, the researchers piloted the survey materials four times (100 respondents each time) to test cover letters and survey questions.  A simple descriptive analysis of the pilot data was completed and will not be included in the research or write-up upon registering the project.

question.value: A short screening questionnaire on Mechanical Turk will make sure that respondents are currently living in the US, have been living in the US for at least ten years, and are at least 18 years of age, and have some work experience in management or human resources. Respondents will then be directed to a Qualtrics survey. Respondents will be compensated $2.00 for 10-15 minutes of work.

q13.value: In accordance with a power analysis, the research team is targeting a sample size of 1250 participants (250 participants per narrative).

q14.value: We used the software program clincalc.com to conduct a power analysis.  Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect an effect size of 15 percentage points at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: We will leave the survey posted on Mechanical Turk for the duration of one month or until our target sample size is reached, whichever happens first.

question.value: The primary outcome variable will be the hiring of one candidate or another. We will measure this by asking participants “Which of the two candidates would you hire for the assistant management role?” From which the respondents will elect Jonathan Smith (no criminal record) or Christopher Williams (criminal record).

This study will implement a logit/probit model to analyze the results, and descriptive analysis to describe the Mechanical Turk sample population. The binary dependent variable is “hired” or “not hired,” whereas the manipulated independent variable is the cover letter narrative.

q22.value: This study is restricted to English speaking Amazon Mechanical Turk workers age 18 and over, living in the US for at least 10 years, who have some management or human resources work experience and have not participated in any of the pilot studies. No other inclusion or exclusion criteria.

attributes.title: Influence of Smartphone notification bings on affect (valence, activation) and happiness
attributes.description:
The usage of smartphones for scientific purposes is gaining more and more popularity (e.g., Fisher & To, 2012). Indeed, smartphones as research tools in the field of psychology bear multiple significant advantages (see Miller, 2012; Raento, Oulasvirta, & Eagle, 2009):

Smartphones seem to be ideally suited as tools for Experience Sampling Methodology (ESM; Hektner, Schmidt, & Csikszentmihalyi, 2007). Experience Sampling  is aiming at studying everyday psychological phenomena in naturalistic settings, asking participants about their momentary behaviour, thoughts, or emotions at various moments. While traditional methods rely on retrospective or generalized self-reports, ESM provides in-situ and in-vivo self-report data (Kahneman, Krueger, Schkade, Schwarz, & Stone, 2004; Mehl & Conner, 2012), thus phenomena are captured where and when they actually occur. Considering repeated measurements in the field, ESM is promising the advantage of enhancing or maximizing ecological validity. Due to their versatile properties, smartphones have eventually already replaced other devices in the ESM context. 

A distinctive characteristic of smartphones compared to other methods is that in most cases they are already owned and used by the respondents. What is an obvious benefit from an economic point of view, could at the same time raise concerns regarding the validity of the results:

Paper-pencil- and PDA-based diaries are designed or programmed for one specific purpose, namely gathering data within the framework of a study. Smartphones, however, already fulfil a vast number of other functions apart from serving as survey tools (e.g., social interactions, information gathering). In the United States, users have on average 35 apps installed on their smartphone, using about one third of these on a daily basis . Pielot, Church, and de Oliveira (2014) found in their study that participants (N=15) received on average 65.3 notifications from different apps per day. Given this vast volume of notifications, smartphone users have to deal with every day, feelings of information overload and satiation seem plausible. Unlike with PDAs, smartphone notifications from several apps must compete for the attention of their users, the rising number of apps installed making it more difficult to distinguish between more or less important bings. Regarding this aspect, participant burden in smartphone-based studies might not be as low as it is believed to be.

It could be shown that notifications can induce negative affects to their recipients: Objective and subjective e-mail and social network (but not messenger) notification counts are positively correlated with negative emotions like the increased feelings of being overwhelmed, stressed, interrupted and annoyed (Pielot et al., 2014). Furthermore, when apps subjectively not perceived as useful continue sending notifications, users become annoyed and consider deleting them from their phones (Felt, Egelman, & Wagner, 2012).
Weber, Voit, Auda, Schneegass, and Henze (2018) allowed their participants (N=16) to explicitly “snooze” the notifications of all apps installed on their smartphones via NHistory, an app specifically developed for this purpose. Main motives for deferring notifications included avoidance of switching contexts, being unable (e.g., while driving), or not being in the mood to react to the prompts. 

In the context of smartphone-based ESM studies, participants typically respond to 2–12 bings per day (see Reis & Gable, 2000). In accordance to app notifications in general, frequent notifications of research apps evoke feelings of annoyance (Church & de Oliveira, 2013; Klasnja, Harrison, LeGrand, LaMarca, Froehlich, & Hudson, 2018; see also van Berkel, Ferreira, & Kostakos, 2017).

Recently, several smartphone-based ESM studies have been conducted measuring affect in different contexts, applying signal-contingent designs. The devices were either provided by the researcher (e.g., Bujarski, Roche, Sheets, Krull, Guzman, & Ray, 2015; Timmons et al., 2017) or the respondents installed a research app on their proprietary smartphones (e.g., Stieger & Lewetz, 2018; Wouters, Jacobs, Duif, Lechner, & Thewissen, 2018). Therefore, the question arises whether the negative mood elicited by the notifications, spills over to the assessment of affect within the ESM design.

q1.value: Influence of Smartphone notification bings on affect (valence, activation) and happiness

q3.value:

q4.value:
When smartphone notifications themselves are evoking specific emotions, what implications can be deduced for signal-based measuring of the latter? Particularly, when measuring momentary affect like anger, is the data gained confounded by the affect caused merely by the beep itself? With the aim of “regaining their freedom”, do respondents also show reactance effects (e.g., higher missing)? 

If beep-induced affect spills over to the measurement of affect in the ESM design, then we expect that participants using their standard notification sound (experimental group) should have higher activation, more negative feelings, and lower happiness scores than participants using the ESM software with our predefined neutral notification sound (control group).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: ESM design about 'personality in everyday life'.  After participants agree to the informed consent, they are randomly assigned either to the 'standard notification' or the 'specific notification' group (i.e., specific notification group uses a sound which was designed by us and should be unique - not used in any other smartphone). We will use three randomized bings per day and additionally an end-of-the-day questionnaire.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A smartphone-based ESM study will be conducted, lasting 3 weeks. Keeping the face validity high, participants will not know our research questions. The official title of the survey will be “personality in everyday life”.
Participants will have to download and install the app ESMira to their Android phones, which is freely available in the Google App Store. Via ESMira, participants will be signalled, questionnaires administered, and responses recorded.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 194 (92 in each group). We will attempt to recruit more than 300 participants to account for dropouts and missings.

q14.value:
Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect even a small effect size of d = 0.2 (alpha = 5%).
According to the calculation method (Twisk) for multilevel-models (3 per day for 21 days = 63 retests; ICC = 0.3) we need a sample size of n = 193.

question.value: We manipulate the standard ring tone of the smartphone by either using the standard sound participants use for their smartphone or a (neutral) sound we designed by including it into the ESM software ESMira.

Affect grid :
Wie angenehm empfinden Sie Ihren momentanen Zustand?	1…sehr unangenehm, 100…sehr angenehm
Wie ist Ihr momentanes Erregungsniveau?	1…Schläfrigkeit, 100…hohe Erregung

Happiness:
Wie glücklich sind Sie momentan? [0..überhaupt nicht, 100..sehr]

Multilevel model by including the experimental variation as predictor. Further predictors: Age, sex,  frequency of having the smartphone set to vibration.

Dependent (criterion) variables will be affect grid and happiness ratings.

q23.value: missings will be part of a exploratory analysis

q24.value: Induced affect by the standard smartphone sound might also heighten the missings, i.e., will be another dependent measure in the multi-level models.

q25.value:

registration_responses.q1: Influence of Smartphone notification bings on affect (valence, activation) and happiness
registration_responses.q3:
The usage of smartphones for scientific purposes is gaining more and more popularity (e.g., Fisher & To, 2012). Indeed, smartphones as research tools in the field of psychology bear multiple significant advantages (see Miller, 2012; Raento, Oulasvirta, & Eagle, 2009):

Smartphones seem to be ideally suited as tools for Experience Sampling Methodology (ESM; Hektner, Schmidt, & Csikszentmihalyi, 2007). Experience Sampling  is aiming at studying everyday psychological phenomena in naturalistic settings, asking participants about their momentary behaviour, thoughts, or emotions at various moments. While traditional methods rely on retrospective or generalized self-reports, ESM provides in-situ and in-vivo self-report data (Kahneman, Krueger, Schkade, Schwarz, & Stone, 2004; Mehl & Conner, 2012), thus phenomena are captured where and when they actually occur. Considering repeated measurements in the field, ESM is promising the advantage of enhancing or maximizing ecological validity. Due to their versatile properties, smartphones have eventually already replaced other devices in the ESM context. 

A distinctive characteristic of smartphones compared to other methods is that in most cases they are already owned and used by the respondents. What is an obvious benefit from an economic point of view, could at the same time raise concerns regarding the validity of the results:

Paper-pencil- and PDA-based diaries are designed or programmed for one specific purpose, namely gathering data within the framework of a study. Smartphones, however, already fulfil a vast number of other functions apart from serving as survey tools (e.g., social interactions, information gathering). In the United States, users have on average 35 apps installed on their smartphone, using about one third of these on a daily basis . Pielot, Church, and de Oliveira (2014) found in their study that participants (N=15) received on average 65.3 notifications from different apps per day. Given this vast volume of notifications, smartphone users have to deal with every day, feelings of information overload and satiation seem plausible. Unlike with PDAs, smartphone notifications from several apps must compete for the attention of their users, the rising number of apps installed making it more difficult to distinguish between more or less important bings. Regarding this aspect, participant burden in smartphone-based studies might not be as low as it is believed to be.

It could be shown that notifications can induce negative affects to their recipients: Objective and subjective e-mail and social network (but not messenger) notification counts are positively correlated with negative emotions like the increased feelings of being overwhelmed, stressed, interrupted and annoyed (Pielot et al., 2014). Furthermore, when apps subjectively not perceived as useful continue sending notifications, users become annoyed and consider deleting them from their phones (Felt, Egelman, & Wagner, 2012).
Weber, Voit, Auda, Schneegass, and Henze (2018) allowed their participants (N=16) to explicitly “snooze” the notifications of all apps installed on their smartphones via NHistory, an app specifically developed for this purpose. Main motives for deferring notifications included avoidance of switching contexts, being unable (e.g., while driving), or not being in the mood to react to the prompts. 

In the context of smartphone-based ESM studies, participants typically respond to 2–12 bings per day (see Reis & Gable, 2000). In accordance to app notifications in general, frequent notifications of research apps evoke feelings of annoyance (Church & de Oliveira, 2013; Klasnja, Harrison, LeGrand, LaMarca, Froehlich, & Hudson, 2018; see also van Berkel, Ferreira, & Kostakos, 2017).

Recently, several smartphone-based ESM studies have been conducted measuring affect in different contexts, applying signal-contingent designs. The devices were either provided by the researcher (e.g., Bujarski, Roche, Sheets, Krull, Guzman, & Ray, 2015; Timmons et al., 2017) or the respondents installed a research app on their proprietary smartphones (e.g., Stieger & Lewetz, 2018; Wouters, Jacobs, Duif, Lechner, & Thewissen, 2018). Therefore, the question arises whether the negative mood elicited by the notifications, spills over to the assessment of affect within the ESM design.
registration_responses.q4:
When smartphone notifications themselves are evoking specific emotions, what implications can be deduced for signal-based measuring of the latter? Particularly, when measuring momentary affect like anger, is the data gained confounded by the affect caused merely by the beep itself? With the aim of “regaining their freedom”, do respondents also show reactance effects (e.g., higher missing)? 

If beep-induced affect spills over to the measurement of affect in the ESM design, then we expect that participants using their standard notification sound (experimental group) should have higher activation, more negative feelings, and lower happiness scores than participants using the ESM software with our predefined neutral notification sound (control group).

attributes.title: Paternalistic altruism and the impact of beliefs about recipients' time preferences

q1.value: The impact of recipients' time preferences on paternalistic altruism

q3.value:
This study investigates the link between paternalism in altruistic behavior and givers' beliefs about the time preferences of recipients. 

Earlier studies have generated evidence that altruism is paternalistic, e.g. with respect to health (see e.g. Jacobsson et al. (2007)). It is possible that this paternalism occurs because givers believe that recipients are impatient or have present-biased preferences, such that they will not use monetary transfers in a way that is relatively beneficial with respect to their future selves. With such beliefs, it can be rational for givers to give gifts in-kind rather than monetary gifts, even in cases where the recipient has stated that he/she prefers money over the gift (but that he/she values the gift positively). 

I run a dictator game-inspired experiment with two treatment groups. In both groups, participants are asked to freely allocate a sum of SEK 1000 between themselves and an anonymous recipient. A transfer to the recipient can be monetary and/or as a gift card at a store specialized in healthy food (such as vegetables and fruit). The recipient has stated that he/she prefers receiving money over such a gift card, but that he/she would accept receiving the gift card. This information is presented to the giver before the allocation decision. 

The difference between the treatment groups lies in which information is provided about the recipient's time preferences. In one group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who in a prestudy has been ranked to have a low willingness to give up something today in order to beneﬁt from that in the future (low patience). In the other treatment group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who has been ranked to have a high such patience. 

Recipients were recruited in a pre-study. The participants of that pre-study were ranked on their patience according to the validated Time Discounting Preference Module: Streamlined Version (Falk et al., 2016).

q4.value:
The study has one main hypothesis and one secondary hypothesis.

The main hypothesis is that the degree of paternalism is higher in the treatment group where the recipient is signalled to have a low patience. In more technical terms, I hypothesize that the the average level of normalized paternalistic gifts is higher in the treatment group where the recipient is signalled to have a low patience, compared to the treatment group where the recipient is signalled to have a high patience. This is hence a directional hypothesis. The null hypothesis is thus that there is no difference between the groups and/or that the difference goes in the other direction. The paternalistic gift level is normalized by dividing the paternalistic gift with the treatment group's average total gift (i.e. the sum of an individual's monetary gift and in-kind gift)  to avoid that effects are driven by changes in total gifts between groups (see the second hypothesis below).

The secondary hypothesis is that the average level of total gifts is different between the treatment groups. Ex-ante, the direction of such an effect is ambiguous. Givers could e.g. think that impatient receivers have a higher need, but they could also think that impatient receivers are not worth helping. The hypothesis is thus non-directional. The null hypothesis is that their is no difference between the treatment groups. 

Statistically, both hypotheses will be tested using two-sided tests.

question.value:
I run a dictator game-inspired experiment with two treatment groups. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the groups. In both groups, participants are asked to freely allocate a sum of SEK 1000 (∼$100) between themselves and an anonymous recipient. The transfer to the recipient can be monetary and/or as a gift card at a store specialized in healthy food (such as vegetables and fruit). Any sum between 0-1000 can be allocated to each of the options, as long as the total sum is equivalent to 1000. Sums below 0 and sums higher than 1000 in any of the boxes lead to an error message. The recipient has stated that he/she prefers receiving money over such a gift card, but that he/she would accept the gift card. This information is presented to the giver before the allocation decision. 

The difference between the treatment groups is the receiver and the information provided about his/her time preferences. In one group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who in a prestudy has been ranked to have a low willingness to give up something today in order to beneﬁt from that in the future (patience). In the other group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who has been ranked to have a high such patience. These treatments are presented in the following way: 

"In a pre-study, real persons were tested and ranked on their willingness to give up something today in order to benefit from that in the future (their patience). 
 
Individual A ranked in the lowest[/highest] 10 %, suggesting that he/she has a low[/high] patience."

The participants will be informed that two individuals who participate in the experiment will be randomly drawn to receive real-life payment in accordance with their answer. One participant from each treatment group will be drawn. 

Recipients were recruited in a pre-study. The participants of that pre-study were ranked on their patience according to the validated Time Discounting Preference Module: Streamlined Version (Falk et al., 2016).  

The experiment will be conducted as an online survey sent out to all students at the Stockholm School of Economics over e-mail. The used survey tool is Qualtrics, a tool that allows for automatic randomization into the two treatments. The students will not know that there is another treatment group than their own. The survey language will be English (SSE students are assumed to have a high enough English proficiency to understand the content).  

At the start of the survey, participants are informed about the payout incentive of the experiment, their anonymity towards other participants, that individual answers will not be looked at (except the submissions drawn for real-life payment) and that the answers will only be used for academic purposes. They are also asked not discuss their participation with other students. The participants are also asked to provide a student e-mail address and to only participate once, as their answers will otherwise be excluded.  

The survey and the e-mail is attached to this page.

The experiment will be conducted as an online survey sent out to all students at the Stockholm School of Economics over e-mail. The survey tool will be Qualtrics, which allows for automatic randomization into treatments. The students will not be informed that there is another treatment group than their own. The survey language will be English (SSE students are assumed to have a high enough English proffiency). 

At the start of the survey, participants are informed about the payout incentive of the experiment, their anonymity towards other participants, that individual answers will not be looked at (except the submissions drawn for real-life payment) and that the answers will only be used for academic purposes. They are also asked not discuss their participation with other students. The participants are also asked to provide a student e-mail address and to only participate once, as their answers will otherwise be excluded.  

Two individuals who participate in the experiment will be randomly drawn to receive real-life payment in accordance with their answers: one student from each of the treatment groups. The recipient will also be paid in accordance with the allocation decision of the drawn student. 

The survey will be published and sent out on January 29, 2020. In the first round, the survey will be open until February 12, 2020. During this period, I will not look at the data nor the number of participants. At February 12, 2020, I will check the number of participants. If this number meets the sample size target specified below, I will close the survey. If the number does not meet the target, I will re-send the link to students who have not participated and keep the survey open until February 19, 2020. I will then again check the participant target and, if this is met, close the survey. If it is not met, I will expand the survey to other universities. I will then target KTH (The Royal Institute of Technology) and Stockholm University students with an invitation e-mail. The procedure will then be similar to the one used for targeting the SSE students. The survey will be open for one additional week, until February 26, 2020, whereafter I will again check the number of participants. If the target is not then met, a reminder will be sent out and the survey will be up for an additional week, until March 4, 2020. This procedure will be repeated until the participation target is met. If needed, I will expand to other universities in Stockholm and thereafter other universities in Sweden. However, expansion from the initial Stockholm School of Economics target group will most likely not be necessary, given participation rates of earlier studies of similar character. 

The survey will be programmed to not allow for any incomplete submissions. Hence, no such incomplete submissions will exist in the dataset and does thus not have to be excluded. 

The survey will ask participants to enter their student e-mail. If a participant has entered another type of e-mail address, that observation will be excluded. This is to prevent analyzing observations from participants that submit several answers using different e-mail addresses. For the same reason, observations where the same e-mail address has been used will all be excluded.

The data will be made publicly available after the experiment. Due to anonymity and integrity reasons, the participants' e-mail addresses will be excluded in that dataset.

question.value:
All participants who submit answers will generate two datapoints of interests: the amount of money allocated as a monetary gift to the recipient (variable name: monetary_gift) and the amount of money allocated as a gift in the form a gift card at a store specialized in healthy food (such as vegetables and fruit) (variable name: paternalistic_gift). These variables can take any number between 0 and 1000. 

(There will also be a third variable generated, the amount of money that the giver allocates to him-/herself, but this is not used in the analysis.)

The dataset will allow to see which treatment the individual has faced, as the treatments are in practice programmed as two different questions (each participant faces only one of the questions). I code these treatments as t_high_patience_receiver and t_low_patience_receiver.

Three measures will be created from the collected data.

The first measure is the total gift for each giver. The total gift is the sum of the monetary gift and the gift in the form of a gift card at a store specialized in healthy food (such as vegetables and fruit) of that giver. The variable name is total_gift, such that total_gift = monetary_gift + paternalistic_gift for each observation.

The second measure is the average total gift, per treatment group. Hence, two averages will be created: average_total_gift_t_high_patience_receiver and average_total_gift_t_low_patience_receiver. These are simply the group averages of the variable total_gift, calculated per treatment group. 

The third measure is a normalization of the paternalistic gift, calculated on the individual level. This measure is constructed as the paternalistic gift of that individual divided by the average total gift level of the treatment group which that individual belongs to. The variable name is paternalistic_gift_normalized, such that paternalistic_gift_normalized = paternalistic_gift / average_total_gift_t_high_patience_receiver for individuals in the high patient treatment group and paternalistic_gift_normalized = paternalistic_gift / average_total_gift_t_low_patience_receiver for individuals in the low patient treatment group. 

The rationale behind this construction is two-fold: First, only analyzing the paternalistic gift level between the two treatment groups could yield a skewed picture, as the total gift level between the groups could vary. Hence, only looking at the paternalistic gift level alone might not capture differences in the relative degree of paternalistic giving behavior. 

Second, using the treatment group's average total gift rather than the individual's total gift level yields the benefit that the variable can be defined also for individuals whose total gift level is zero. Note that this relies on the assumption that the average total gift level is not zero in any of the treatment groups. This is deemed to be a reasonable assumption, given the large amount of prior studies who find altruistic behavior in dictator game settings.

The two hypotheses will be tested using two-tailed Mann-Whitney U tests. The first test will test whether the average normalized paternalistic gift level is different between the treatment groups. The second test will test whether the average total gift level is different between the treatment groups. The null hypothesis in both tests is that there is no difference between the treatment groups. 

I choose to use a non-parametric test as dictator games responses typically does not follow a normal distribution.

q21.value: Following Benjamin et al. (2018), the null hypotheses will be rejected for p-values under the threshold of 0.005. P-values that lies between 0.05 and 0.005 will be considered as suggestive evidence. The tests will be two-tailed.

registration_responses.q1: The impact of recipients' time preferences on paternalistic altruism
registration_responses.q3:
This study investigates the link between paternalism in altruistic behavior and givers' beliefs about the time preferences of recipients. 

Earlier studies have generated evidence that altruism is paternalistic, e.g. with respect to health (see e.g. Jacobsson et al. (2007)). It is possible that this paternalism occurs because givers believe that recipients are impatient or have present-biased preferences, such that they will not use monetary transfers in a way that is relatively beneficial with respect to their future selves. With such beliefs, it can be rational for givers to give gifts in-kind rather than monetary gifts, even in cases where the recipient has stated that he/she prefers money over the gift (but that he/she values the gift positively). 

I run a dictator game-inspired experiment with two treatment groups. In both groups, participants are asked to freely allocate a sum of SEK 1000 between themselves and an anonymous recipient. A transfer to the recipient can be monetary and/or as a gift card at a store specialized in healthy food (such as vegetables and fruit). The recipient has stated that he/she prefers receiving money over such a gift card, but that he/she would accept receiving the gift card. This information is presented to the giver before the allocation decision. 

The difference between the treatment groups lies in which information is provided about the recipient's time preferences. In one group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who in a prestudy has been ranked to have a low willingness to give up something today in order to beneﬁt from that in the future (low patience). In the other treatment group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who has been ranked to have a high such patience. 

Recipients were recruited in a pre-study. The participants of that pre-study were ranked on their patience according to the validated Time Discounting Preference Module: Streamlined Version (Falk et al., 2016).
registration_responses.q4:
The study has one main hypothesis and one secondary hypothesis.

The main hypothesis is that the degree of paternalism is higher in the treatment group where the recipient is signalled to have a low patience. In more technical terms, I hypothesize that the the average level of normalized paternalistic gifts is higher in the treatment group where the recipient is signalled to have a low patience, compared to the treatment group where the recipient is signalled to have a high patience. This is hence a directional hypothesis. The null hypothesis is thus that there is no difference between the groups and/or that the difference goes in the other direction. The paternalistic gift level is normalized by dividing the paternalistic gift with the treatment group's average total gift (i.e. the sum of an individual's monetary gift and in-kind gift)  to avoid that effects are driven by changes in total gifts between groups (see the second hypothesis below).

The secondary hypothesis is that the average level of total gifts is different between the treatment groups. Ex-ante, the direction of such an effect is ambiguous. Givers could e.g. think that impatient receivers have a higher need, but they could also think that impatient receivers are not worth helping. The hypothesis is thus non-directional. The null hypothesis is that their is no difference between the treatment groups. 

Statistically, both hypotheses will be tested using two-sided tests.

registration_responses.q8.question:
I run a dictator game-inspired experiment with two treatment groups. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the groups. In both groups, participants are asked to freely allocate a sum of SEK 1000 (∼$100) between themselves and an anonymous recipient. The transfer to the recipient can be monetary and/or as a gift card at a store specialized in healthy food (such as vegetables and fruit). Any sum between 0-1000 can be allocated to each of the options, as long as the total sum is equivalent to 1000. Sums below 0 and sums higher than 1000 in any of the boxes lead to an error message. The recipient has stated that he/she prefers receiving money over such a gift card, but that he/she would accept the gift card. This information is presented to the giver before the allocation decision. 

The difference between the treatment groups is the receiver and the information provided about his/her time preferences. In one group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who in a prestudy has been ranked to have a low willingness to give up something today in order to beneﬁt from that in the future (patience). In the other group, givers face an allocation situation with a recipient who has been ranked to have a high such patience. These treatments are presented in the following way: 

"In a pre-study, real persons were tested and ranked on their willingness to give up something today in order to benefit from that in the future (their patience). 
 
Individual A ranked in the lowest[/highest] 10 %, suggesting that he/she has a low[/high] patience."

The participants will be informed that two individuals who participate in the experiment will be randomly drawn to receive real-life payment in accordance with their answer. One participant from each treatment group will be drawn. 

Recipients were recruited in a pre-study. The participants of that pre-study were ranked on their patience according to the validated Time Discounting Preference Module: Streamlined Version (Falk et al., 2016).  

The experiment will be conducted as an online survey sent out to all students at the Stockholm School of Economics over e-mail. The used survey tool is Qualtrics, a tool that allows for automatic randomization into the two treatments. The students will not know that there is another treatment group than their own. The survey language will be English (SSE students are assumed to have a high enough English proficiency to understand the content).  

At the start of the survey, participants are informed about the payout incentive of the experiment, their anonymity towards other participants, that individual answers will not be looked at (except the submissions drawn for real-life payment) and that the answers will only be used for academic purposes. They are also asked not discuss their participation with other students. The participants are also asked to provide a student e-mail address and to only participate once, as their answers will otherwise be excluded.  

The survey and the e-mail is attached to this page.

The second measure is the average total gift, per treatment group. Hence, two averages will be created: average_total_gift_t_high_patience_receiver and average_total_gift_t_low_patience_receiver. These are simply the group averages of the variable total_gift, calculated per treatment group.

The rationale behind this construction is two-fold: First, only analyzing the paternalistic gift level between the two treatment groups could yield a skewed picture, as the total gift level between the groups could vary. Hence, only looking at the paternalistic gift level alone might not capture differences in the relative degree of paternalistic giving behavior. 

Second, using the treatment group's average total gift rather than the individual's total gift level yields the benefit that the variable can be defined also for individuals whose total gift level is zero. Note that this relies on the assumption that the average total gift level is not zero in any of the treatment groups. This is deemed to be a reasonable assumption, given the large amount of prior studies who find altruistic behavior in dictator game settings.
