other.value:
As secondary hypotheses, we theorize that preference for consistency (PFC) will serve as a moderator and unfreezing will serve as a mediator. In previous work, blatant dehumanization had an indirect effect on Support for anti-Muslim Policies so we predict blatant dehumanization will again have an indirect effect on Support for anti-Muslim Policies in all experimental conditions. We will also introduce the role of feeling shamed in the intervention. If feeling shamed is affected differently by the different conditions, then we will test it as a mediator, but if it is similarly affected by all three manipulations, or not affected at all by any of them, we will test shame as a moderator. We will also analyze some exploratory variables: symbolic threat, realistic threat and terroristic threat as potential dependent variables and mediators. 
Our potential moderators are: (1) Preference for Consistency and (2) Shame.
Our potential mediators are: (1) Unfreezing, (2) Shame, (3) Symbolic Threat, (4) Realistic Threat and (5) Terroristic  Threat.
In exploratory analysis, we will examine whether participants’ religion or political affiliation has any moderating effects on the effect of experimental condition on any of the DVs. Christian participants will be labelled as ‘1’ and non-Christian participants will be labelled as ‘0’. Democratic participants will be labeled as ‘1’ and Republican participants will be labelled as ‘0’.

sample.value: We will mirror our previous study and recruit 200 participants per condition. In our previous study, we conducted a power analysis that indicated 76 participants per group will be required to detect a medium effect (d= .5) with .95 power. Samples of 436 per condition would be required to detect a small effect size (d=.2). Balancing our desire to have high power to detect small effects with budgetary constraints, we will recruit at least 200 participants per condition. This allowed us to detect an effect size of d= .3 with .95 power.

analyses.value:
We will run one-way ANOVAs across all conditions and LSD post-hoc analysis, which will be followed-up by t-tests between each condition and the control, for each of the outcome measures.
Using Hayes’s (2018) PROCESS macro for SPSS, we will test for mediation and moderation, as described above, with our potential mediators and moderators, i.e., unfreezing, preference for consistency, and feeling shamed. We will test the differences between the two versions of condition 3, the CBH activity followed by the CPH activity (version 1) and the CPH activity followed by the CBH activity (version 2). If there is no difference between the two versions, we will combine responses across these conditions and treat them as one condition.

outliers.value: Sample sizes will be pre-determined in Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, and we will not examine the data until the full sample is collected. We will also exclude all participants who identify as Muslim and who fail an attention check question embedded in the survey.

dependent.value:
We will measure all dependent variables using self-report questionnaires. Order of presentation of items on each scale, and the presentation order of each DV will be randomized across participants.

The dependent variables: 
(1) Collective blame will be assessed by a brief description of the Belgium terror attacks (“In March, 2016, three Muslim extremists killed 32 people and wounded over 300 at the Brussels airport in Belgium. How responsible do you think Muslims are for this attack?”) and having participants report how responsible they feel “Muslims in general” and “Belgium Muslims” were for the attacks using unmarked sliders anchored at 0 (not at all) and 100 (very much) (Bruneau, Kteily, & Falk, 2018).  We will use only the measure of “Muslims in general” as our measure of collective blame.
(2) Blatant dehumanization will be assessed by two measures (presentation of each measure relative to the other will be randomized): the trait measure and Ascent Dehumanization scale (Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015). The trait measure asks participants how well a series of eight dehumanizing traits/trait pairs (e.g., “savage,” “unsophisticated,” “barbaric, coldhearted”; Bastian & Haslam, 2010; Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015) apply to Muslims, and how well they apply to Christians (order of presentation of each target group will be randomized across participants). The Ascent Dehumanization scale (Kteily et al., 2015) presents participants with the popular “Ascent of (Hu)Man” diagram and asks them to determine where target groups fall on the scale, from the quadrupedal early human ancestor (0) to fully “evolved” modern human (100). We will assess ‘ascent dehumanization’ towards Muslims, Christians, and other filler groups (presentation order of all groups will be randomized across participants). Consistent with previous work, we will assess dehumanization as a difference score (here, between Muslims and Christians), and we will then standardize the ratings on each scale and average these two dehumanization measures to provide a single measure of dehumanization. 
(3) Anti-Muslim policy support will be assessed by asking participants to indicate their support for five policies targeting Muslims based on previous scales from Kteily and Bruneau (2017), Lee et. al., (2009), and Schildkraut (2009); sample items include “We need to stop accepting Muslim immigrants into this country, period” and “We should institute a database that keeps track of Muslims in this country.” Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).

Exploratory dependent variables:
(4) Symbolic Threat will be assessed by asking participants to indicate their agreement with 3 items suggesting Muslims are threating American beliefs or values based on Uenal (2016); sample items include “I am worried that the American culture is endangered by Islam” and “I am worried that American rights and freedom are threatened by the presence of Muslims”. Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).
(5) Realistic Threat will be assessed by asking participants to indicate their agreement with 4 items suggesting Muslims pose a danger to Americans’ well-being based on Uenal (2016); sample items include “The presence of Islam in America threatens our economic prosperity” and “Because of the presence of Islam, the education system in America is threatened”. Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).
(6) Terroristic Threat will be assessed with using three items developed by Uenal (2016); sample item include “I am worried that the peace is threatened by radical Islamist groups in the U.S.”. Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).

Moderator:
(1) Preference for consistency (PFC) will be assessed by an abridged 6-item version of the preference for consistency (PFC) scale developed by Cialdini, Trost, and Newsom (1995). 

Mediator:
(1) Unfreezing will be assessed using 4items indicating the extent, from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much so), to which the survey made them doubt notions of Muslims (i.e., “Muslims hate many of the freedoms that we hold dear in the U.S.”) as developed by Hameiri et. al., (2014).

Moderator or Mediator:
(1) Shame will be assessed with one item, asking participants how proud versus how ashamed of their American identity they feel the people who created this survey want them to feel on a Likert-type scale anchored at 1 (proud) and (7) ashamed.

conditions.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to either one of the 3 experimental conditions or the control:
The first condition will be the CBH activity: four consecutive examples of Christian extremists engaging in violent actions, followed by three consecutive examples of Muslim extremists engaging in violent actions. After presenting the examples, participants will be asked to report how responsible they think Christians/Muslims are for the violent actions of a Christian extremist/Muslim extremist?
The second condition will be the CPH activity we found to be the most effective in a previous study: three consecutive examples of Muslim organizations engaging in prosocial behavior, followed by three consecutive examples of Christian organizations engaging in prosocial behavior. After presenting the examples, participants will be asked to report how well they think the actions of the Christian/Muslim group reflect on Christians/Muslims, in general. 
The third condition will combine the two interventions: displaying of either the CBH activity followed by the CPH activity or the CPH activity followed by the CBH activity.  
The last condition will be a control group, in which none of the events will be presented, and participants will be sent instead straight to the survey. In all 3 experimental conditions, participants will be sent to the survey immediately after evaluating the events.
We speculate condition one (CBH manipulation) will be more effective than condition 2 (CPH manipulation) in reducing anti-Muslim attitudes and behaviors. We do not have a clear prediction of how effective condition 3 (combined CBH and CPH) will be compared to the other two experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value:
In previous work, we used a novel hypocrisy paradigm - reminiscent of cognitive dissonance induction paradigms - to reduce anti-Muslim attitudes and behavior. In the Collective Blame Hypocrisy activity (CBH; Bruneau, Kteily, & Falk, 2018), non-Muslim participants are asked to report how responsible Muslims are for the actions of Muslim extremists after first reporting how responsible they hold themselves, White Americans/Christians for the actions of White/Christian extremists. We will run the CBH activity as in (Bruneau, Kteily, & Falk, 2018); however, instead of providing examples of White extremists and asking participants to report responsibility of White Americans, we will provide examples of Christian extremist violence and ask participants to report responsibility of Christians. This will provide better parity with the Collective Praise Hypocrisy activity, which focuses on Muslims and Christians.
In a previous study, we explored the effects of a novel hypocrisy paradigm in building parity between the prosocial actions by groups of Muslims versus groups of Christians. In the CPH activity, non-Muslim participants are asked to report how well they think benevolent actions of Christian groups should reflect on Christians, in general after first reporting how well they think benevolent actions of Muslim groups should reflect on Muslims, in general.
The present study will combine and compare the CBH activity and the CPH activity to determine the effectiveness of each at reducing anti-Muslim attitudes and behavior, and if their effects are additive. We will also attempt to uncover the psychological mechanisms underlying the effects of each intervention. 
Irrespective of the mechanism, we predict that these interventions will improve evaluations of Muslims by reducing dehumanization of Muslims. We also predict that the CBH activity will reduce collective blame of Muslims (the target perceptions of the intervention); and we will determine if CPH also reduces collective blame of Muslims. The other two outcomes we will assess are and (3) anti-Muslim policy support. We predict that both of these outcomes will be reduced by the interventions.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Study 3: Collective Blame/Collective Praise
registration_responses.other:
As secondary hypotheses, we theorize that preference for consistency (PFC) will serve as a moderator and unfreezing will serve as a mediator. In previous work, blatant dehumanization had an indirect effect on Support for anti-Muslim Policies so we predict blatant dehumanization will again have an indirect effect on Support for anti-Muslim Policies in all experimental conditions. We will also introduce the role of feeling shamed in the intervention. If feeling shamed is affected differently by the different conditions, then we will test it as a mediator, but if it is similarly affected by all three manipulations, or not affected at all by any of them, we will test shame as a moderator. We will also analyze some exploratory variables: symbolic threat, realistic threat and terroristic threat as potential dependent variables and mediators. 
Our potential moderators are: (1) Preference for Consistency and (2) Shame.
Our potential mediators are: (1) Unfreezing, (2) Shame, (3) Symbolic Threat, (4) Realistic Threat and (5) Terroristic  Threat.
In exploratory analysis, we will examine whether participants’ religion or political affiliation has any moderating effects on the effect of experimental condition on any of the DVs. Christian participants will be labelled as ‘1’ and non-Christian participants will be labelled as ‘0’. Democratic participants will be labeled as ‘1’ and Republican participants will be labelled as ‘0’.
registration_responses.sample: We will mirror our previous study and recruit 200 participants per condition. In our previous study, we conducted a power analysis that indicated 76 participants per group will be required to detect a medium effect (d= .5) with .95 power. Samples of 436 per condition would be required to detect a small effect size (d=.2). Balancing our desire to have high power to detect small effects with budgetary constraints, we will recruit at least 200 participants per condition. This allowed us to detect an effect size of d= .3 with .95 power.
registration_responses.analyses:
We will run one-way ANOVAs across all conditions and LSD post-hoc analysis, which will be followed-up by t-tests between each condition and the control, for each of the outcome measures.
Using Hayes’s (2018) PROCESS macro for SPSS, we will test for mediation and moderation, as described above, with our potential mediators and moderators, i.e., unfreezing, preference for consistency, and feeling shamed. We will test the differences between the two versions of condition 3, the CBH activity followed by the CPH activity (version 1) and the CPH activity followed by the CBH activity (version 2). If there is no difference between the two versions, we will combine responses across these conditions and treat them as one condition.
registration_responses.outliers: Sample sizes will be pre-determined in Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, and we will not examine the data until the full sample is collected. We will also exclude all participants who identify as Muslim and who fail an attention check question embedded in the survey.
registration_responses.dependent:
We will measure all dependent variables using self-report questionnaires. Order of presentation of items on each scale, and the presentation order of each DV will be randomized across participants.

The dependent variables: 
(1) Collective blame will be assessed by a brief description of the Belgium terror attacks (“In March, 2016, three Muslim extremists killed 32 people and wounded over 300 at the Brussels airport in Belgium. How responsible do you think Muslims are for this attack?”) and having participants report how responsible they feel “Muslims in general” and “Belgium Muslims” were for the attacks using unmarked sliders anchored at 0 (not at all) and 100 (very much) (Bruneau, Kteily, & Falk, 2018).  We will use only the measure of “Muslims in general” as our measure of collective blame.
(2) Blatant dehumanization will be assessed by two measures (presentation of each measure relative to the other will be randomized): the trait measure and Ascent Dehumanization scale (Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015). The trait measure asks participants how well a series of eight dehumanizing traits/trait pairs (e.g., “savage,” “unsophisticated,” “barbaric, coldhearted”; Bastian & Haslam, 2010; Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015) apply to Muslims, and how well they apply to Christians (order of presentation of each target group will be randomized across participants). The Ascent Dehumanization scale (Kteily et al., 2015) presents participants with the popular “Ascent of (Hu)Man” diagram and asks them to determine where target groups fall on the scale, from the quadrupedal early human ancestor (0) to fully “evolved” modern human (100). We will assess ‘ascent dehumanization’ towards Muslims, Christians, and other filler groups (presentation order of all groups will be randomized across participants). Consistent with previous work, we will assess dehumanization as a difference score (here, between Muslims and Christians), and we will then standardize the ratings on each scale and average these two dehumanization measures to provide a single measure of dehumanization. 
(3) Anti-Muslim policy support will be assessed by asking participants to indicate their support for five policies targeting Muslims based on previous scales from Kteily and Bruneau (2017), Lee et. al., (2009), and Schildkraut (2009); sample items include “We need to stop accepting Muslim immigrants into this country, period” and “We should institute a database that keeps track of Muslims in this country.” Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).

Exploratory dependent variables:
(4) Symbolic Threat will be assessed by asking participants to indicate their agreement with 3 items suggesting Muslims are threating American beliefs or values based on Uenal (2016); sample items include “I am worried that the American culture is endangered by Islam” and “I am worried that American rights and freedom are threatened by the presence of Muslims”. Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).
(5) Realistic Threat will be assessed by asking participants to indicate their agreement with 4 items suggesting Muslims pose a danger to Americans’ well-being based on Uenal (2016); sample items include “The presence of Islam in America threatens our economic prosperity” and “Because of the presence of Islam, the education system in America is threatened”. Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).
(6) Terroristic Threat will be assessed with using three items developed by Uenal (2016); sample item include “I am worried that the peace is threatened by radical Islamist groups in the U.S.”. Responses will be made on 7-point Likert-type scales anchored at 1 (strongly disagree) and 7 (strongly agree).

Moderator:
(1) Preference for consistency (PFC) will be assessed by an abridged 6-item version of the preference for consistency (PFC) scale developed by Cialdini, Trost, and Newsom (1995). 

Mediator:
(1) Unfreezing will be assessed using 4items indicating the extent, from 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much so), to which the survey made them doubt notions of Muslims (i.e., “Muslims hate many of the freedoms that we hold dear in the U.S.”) as developed by Hameiri et. al., (2014).

Moderator or Mediator:
(1) Shame will be assessed with one item, asking participants how proud versus how ashamed of their American identity they feel the people who created this survey want them to feel on a Likert-type scale anchored at 1 (proud) and (7) ashamed.
registration_responses.conditions:
Participants will be randomly assigned to either one of the 3 experimental conditions or the control:
The first condition will be the CBH activity: four consecutive examples of Christian extremists engaging in violent actions, followed by three consecutive examples of Muslim extremists engaging in violent actions. After presenting the examples, participants will be asked to report how responsible they think Christians/Muslims are for the violent actions of a Christian extremist/Muslim extremist?
The second condition will be the CPH activity we found to be the most effective in a previous study: three consecutive examples of Muslim organizations engaging in prosocial behavior, followed by three consecutive examples of Christian organizations engaging in prosocial behavior. After presenting the examples, participants will be asked to report how well they think the actions of the Christian/Muslim group reflect on Christians/Muslims, in general. 
The third condition will combine the two interventions: displaying of either the CBH activity followed by the CPH activity or the CPH activity followed by the CBH activity.  
The last condition will be a control group, in which none of the events will be presented, and participants will be sent instead straight to the survey. In all 3 experimental conditions, participants will be sent to the survey immediately after evaluating the events.
We speculate condition one (CBH manipulation) will be more effective than condition 2 (CPH manipulation) in reducing anti-Muslim attitudes and behaviors. We do not have a clear prediction of how effective condition 3 (combined CBH and CPH) will be compared to the other two experimental conditions.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In previous work, we used a novel hypocrisy paradigm - reminiscent of cognitive dissonance induction paradigms - to reduce anti-Muslim attitudes and behavior. In the Collective Blame Hypocrisy activity (CBH; Bruneau, Kteily, & Falk, 2018), non-Muslim participants are asked to report how responsible Muslims are for the actions of Muslim extremists after first reporting how responsible they hold themselves, White Americans/Christians for the actions of White/Christian extremists. We will run the CBH activity as in (Bruneau, Kteily, & Falk, 2018); however, instead of providing examples of White extremists and asking participants to report responsibility of White Americans, we will provide examples of Christian extremist violence and ask participants to report responsibility of Christians. This will provide better parity with the Collective Praise Hypocrisy activity, which focuses on Muslims and Christians.
In a previous study, we explored the effects of a novel hypocrisy paradigm in building parity between the prosocial actions by groups of Muslims versus groups of Christians. In the CPH activity, non-Muslim participants are asked to report how well they think benevolent actions of Christian groups should reflect on Christians, in general after first reporting how well they think benevolent actions of Muslim groups should reflect on Muslims, in general.
The present study will combine and compare the CBH activity and the CPH activity to determine the effectiveness of each at reducing anti-Muslim attitudes and behavior, and if their effects are additive. We will also attempt to uncover the psychological mechanisms underlying the effects of each intervention. 
Irrespective of the mechanism, we predict that these interventions will improve evaluations of Muslims by reducing dehumanization of Muslims. We also predict that the CBH activity will reduce collective blame of Muslims (the target perceptions of the intervention); and we will determine if CPH also reduces collective blame of Muslims. The other two outcomes we will assess are and (3) anti-Muslim policy support. We predict that both of these outcomes will be reduced by the interventions.

attributes.title: Framing effects on the effectiveness and virality of health messages related to COVID-19
attributes.description: The opinions and behaviors of peers are potent factors influencing human decision making (Cialdini & Goldstein, 2004). As such, a number of studies have demonstrated that descriptive norm-based messages can be effective at influencing individuals’ behavior through changing their perceived norms. Such health campaigns have been carried out in the U.S., Canada, and the UK, and targeted a number of risky and health behaviors, such as drug use, alcohol consumption, and tobacco use (e.g. Arbour-Nicitopoulos, Kwan, Lowe, Taman, & Faulkner, 2010; Cislaghi & Heise, 2018; Donaldson et al., 1994; Larimer & Neighbors, 2003; Liu & Shi, 2019; Neighbors et al., 2004). In addition to descriptive norms, other persuasive appeals (such as autonomy and humor) have shown to be effective at influencing people’s health-related beliefs and behaviors. In the proposed study, we assess the social relevance and favorability of norm-based covid-19 social distancing messages (e.g. messages that highlight people staying home and avoiding crowds) as well as their effectiveness in shifting people’s perceived social distancing norms. In addition, we will examine the interaction effects of individuals’ interdependent self-construal and experimental condition (norms/autonomous/humor) on perceived social distancing norms.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Testing the effectiveness of descriptive norm interventions at changing COVID-19 related norm perceptions.

other.value:
We will conduct the following secondary analyses to compliment the above primary analyses. See below for descriptions of DVs and covariates used for secondary analyses. 

Analyses 1 - 4 are related message level ratings other than social relevance and favorability. Based on pilot data, descriptive norm condition (relative to message control condition) had a smaller effect on these message ratings (self relevance, self motivation, other motivation, and sharing intention). As such, we propose these analyses in the secondary section. These analyses will be conducted in participants in descriptive norm and in message control condition, at participant x message level. 

1. Investigate the effect of descriptive norm condition on  intentions. This effect will be tested using a multilevel mixed effects model specified as below:
md = lmer(message favorability ~ condition + age + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))

2. Investigate the effect of descriptive norm condition on  intentions. This effect will be tested using a multilevel mixed effects model specified as below:
md = lmer(self motivation ~ condition + age + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))

3. Investigate the effect of descriptive norm condition on  intentions. This effect will be tested using a multilevel mixed effects model specified as below:
md = lmer(other motivation ~ condition + age + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))

4. Investigate the effect of descriptive norm condition on  intentions. This effect will be tested using a multilevel mixed effects model specified as below:
md = lmer(sharing intention ~ condition + age + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))


Secondary Analyses 5 -7 are related to individuals’ social distancing intentions, beliefs, and perceived norms of close friends and family. In our pilot data, participants’ behavioral intentions and belief were already high, and there was a ceiling effect in the extent that norm conditions can shift participants in these two areas, hence we frame them as secondary analyses. With regards to perceived norms of close friends and family, we expect that participants will base their norm perceptions of close friends and family on social interactions and daily communications, and thus we were uncertain whether descriptive norm manipulation can successfully shift people’s perception in this area. These analyses will be conducted in participants in descriptive norm and in message control condition. 

5. Investigate the effect of descriptive norm condition on participant's social distancing intentions. This effect will be tested using a linear regression model specified as below:
md = lm(social distancing intentions ~ condition + age)

6. Investigate the effect of condition on participant's COVID-19 beliefs. We will separately investigate the effect of condition on participants’ social distancing self beliefs, social distancing other beliefs, and social distancing norm beliefs (described below). This effect will be tested using linear regression models specified as below:
md = lm(social distancing self beliefs ~ condition + age)
md = lm(social distancing other beliefs ~ condition + age)
md = lm(social distancing norm beliefs ~ condition + age)

7.  Investigate the effect of condition on participant's perceived social distance norm of close friends and family. This effect will be tested using a linear regression model specified as below:
md = lm(social distancing norms_close ~ condition + age, data = df)

Analyses 8 - 10 are related to age x condition interaction on participants’ message ratings as well as perceived norms, comparing participants in descriptive norm condition with participants in message control condition: 

8. Investigate if there is an age x condition interaction on message social relevance. This interaction will be tested using the multilevel model specified as below:
lmer(message relevance ~ age + condition +  age*condition + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))

9. Investigate if there is an age x condition interaction on message favorability. 
This interaction will be tested using the multilevel model specified as below:
lmer(message favorability ~ age + condition +  age*condition + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))

10. Investigate if there is an age x condition interaction on participants’ perceived norms.This interaction will be tested using the linear regression model specified as below:
lmer(norm_town_socialdis ~ age + condition +  age*condition + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))

Analysis 11 concerns the type of normative messages:

11. All our descriptive norm messages were written using one of the following three pronouns: “I”, “we”, “most people”. For instance:
“I” message: Social distancing is critical for reducing exposure to #covid19.  I am staying home to stop hundreds of others from being infected.
“We” message: Social distancing is critical for reducing exposure to #covid19.  We are staying home to stop hundreds of others from being infected.
“Most people” message: Social distancing is critical for reducing exposure to #covid19.  Most people are staying home to stop hundreds of others from being infected.

We will investigate if different wording of descriptive norm messages (using either “I”, “we”, or “most people”) has an effect on participants’ ratings on message favorability, motivation, and relevance, compared to the control condition. This analysis will be conducted in participants in the descriptive norm and message control conditions, and this will be tested using multilevel models specified as below:

lmer(self motivation ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(other motivation ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(self relevance ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(social relevance   ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(message favorability ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(sharing intention ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))

We will also explore how covariates (e.g. gender, interdependence self-construal, independence self-construal, SES, political orientation and partisanship etc.) affect the primary analyses. To do so, we will use specification curve analysis to assess the robustness of exploratory effects across different model specifications. We will collect an additional sample to replicate any findings identified using exploratory methods.

Variable definitions:
Self relevance: This message is relevant to me (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Self motivation: This message motivates me to avoid physical contact with others (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Other motivation: This message would motivate people I know to avoid physical contact with others (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Sharing intention: I would share this message on social media (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Interdependence self construal (averaged):
Listed below are a number of statements. Read each one as if it referred to you.
In general, groups I belong to are an important part of my self-image. 
It is important for me to maintain harmony with my group.
I often have the feeling that my relationships with others are more important than my own accomplishments.
I feel good when I cooperate with others. 

Social distancing intentions (average):
Please rate how much you intend to do the following things over the next two weeks.
Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if I’m not sick. 
Limit my grocery shopping to once a week or less.
Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when I’m in public.
Avoid all public gatherings, even if I’m not sick.

Social distancing self beliefs (average).
If I stay home everyday for the next two weeks, and avoid social contact,  even if I’m not sick (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree):
I will avoid coming in contact with coronavirus. 
I will be less likely to get COVID-19.
I will be less likely to get sick.
I will keep myself safe. 
I will be able to take care of myself.

Social distancing others beliefs (average). 
If I stay home everyday for the next two weeks, and avoid social contact,  even if I’m not sick (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree):
I will keep my family safe. 
I will keep people in my community safe. 
I will prevent others from getting COVID-19.
I will protect more vulnerable people in our society.
I will slow the spread of COVID-19. 
It will be good for society.
It will help stop the spread of COVID-19.
It will help the healthcare system from being over flooded and enable people who need urgent medical care to receive it. 

Social distance norm beliefs (average)
If I stay home everyday for the next two weeks, and avoid social contact,  even if I’m not sick (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree):
It will be awkward to avoid my friends. (Reversed)
My friends will approve of my decision. 
My family will approve of my decision. 
People I work with will approve of my decision. 

Social distancing norms_close (average)
For these questions, think about your closest friends and family. What proportion of them… (0%-100%) 
Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if they aren’t sick. 
Limit their grocery shopping to once a week or less. 
Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when they’re in public. 
Avoid all public gatherings, even if they aren’t sick.

sample.value:
We conducted a small pilot study to assess potential effect sizes and variance parameters. Based on these results, we conducted a power analysis using the PANGEA power calculator (https://jakewestfall.shinyapps.io/pangea/) and determined we would have >80% power to detect an effect size of d = .2 for within- and between-subject effects with N = 200 per experimental condition.

As such, according to the sample size calculation, and assuming an exclusion rate of 10% (see exclusion criteria), we propose to recruit approximately 220 participants per condition.

analyses.value:
Since the analyses in this pre-registration are primarily focused on the effectiveness of descriptive norms, unless otherwise stated, analyses will be conducted in participants in descriptive norm and message control conditions only. Please see other pre-registrations in the same project (https://osf.io/8hn2g/) for analyses related to the autonomy and humor conditions. 

For each of the following analyses, we will first test if age is significantly associate with the respective DV. If so, age will be included as covariates in the model. 

1. Two mixed effect multilevel models will be constructed to investigate the favorability and social relevance ratings of messages in descriptive norm condition compared to control condition. The models will be specified as below, at the message x participant level:

md = lmer(message favorability ~ condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))
md = lmer(social relevance ~ condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))

We predict that there will be a positive fixed effect of condition (reference level: control) for both models, at significance level p < .05. 


2. A linear regression model will be constructed to compare perceived norms of participants in control vs. descriptive norm condition. The model will be specified as below:

md = lm(norm_town_socialdis ~ condition)

We predict that condition (reference level: control condition) will have a positive regression coefficient, significance level at p < .05. 


3. To test for a positive association between interdependence and perceived norm for participants in the no message condition, the following linear regression model will be constructed: 

md = lm(norm_town_socialdis ~ interdependence)

We predict that interdependence will have a positive regression coefficient, significance level at p < .05. The interdependence measure is defined in the Secondary Analysis section. 

4. A multiple linear regression model will be constructed to test the interaction effect between interdependence and condition. This analysis will be conducted in all participants across all message conditions (excluding participants in the no message control condition). A multiple regression model will be constructed as specified below: 

md = lm(norm_town_socialdis ~ condition * interdependence + condition + interdependence ) 

In this model, control condition will be set as reference level, with the experimental conditions (norm, autonomous and humor) will be treated as one level (experimental).

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded according to the criteria in the standard operating procedures for this project listed on OSF: https://osf.io/8hn2g/.

dependent.value:
1. Perceived social norms (Measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following four questions will be used.)

For these questions, think about people in your city or town. What proportion of them… (0%-100%) 
Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if they aren’t sick.
Limit their grocery shopping to once a week or less.
Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when they’re in public. 
Avoid all public gatherings, even if they aren’t sick.

2. Message Social relevance (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree)

This message is relevant to other people I know. 

3. Message Favorability (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree; calculated by subtracting question 2 from question 1)

(1) The message put thoughts in my mind about wanting to avoid physical contact with others. 
(2) The message put thoughts in my mind about not wanting to avoid physical contact with others.

conditions.value:
Participants will be assigned to one of the following five conditions: descriptive norm, autonomy, humor, message control, or no message control condition (https://osf.io/8hn2g/). Each participant will see a series of 5 messages about covid19 randomly sampled from a pool of 15 messages in each condition (other than the no message control condition). Each message is created to look like an Instagram post that includes a visual message about covid-19 accompanied by a “post” about the message. Messages from experimental conditions (humor/norms/autonomy) and the message control condition have the same image, but the text accompanying the images were manipulated such that the control condition includes only a message about covid-19, where as 1) the descriptive norm condition includes the control message as well as information regarding the descriptive norm surrounding social distancing, 2) the humorous condition includes the control message as in addition to a humorous statement ridiculing behaviors which do not follow social distancing, and 3) the autonomous condition contains additional text framed using autonomous language. Participants in the no message control condition will not be exposed to any messages. 


Example from Control condition: Staying home protects our community by stopping the spread of #covid19.

Example from Descriptive norm condition: Staying home protects our community by stopping the of #covid19. Many people are staying home today to help each other in this pandemic.

Example from Humorous condition: Staying home helps stop the spread of #coronavirus. And yet some people will insist on NOT working from home. Why? Cause you miss passing by co-workers on the way to the bathroom?

Example from Autonomous condition: Staying home protects our community by stopping the spread of #covid19. Your choices have immense power to help others!

hypothesis.value:
1. Descriptive norm messages will be rated as more favorable and socially relevant compared to control messages. 

2. Compared to participants in the control condition, participants in the descriptive norm condition will show higher levels of perceived norms regarding social distancing behavior in people in their town/city. 

（Note: we also plan to measure perceived social distancing norms in close family and friends, which is listed as secondary analysis in the Other section. We expect that individuals’ norm perceptions of their close friends and family will be mainly based on direct social interactions. On the other hand, individuals’ norm perceptions of people in their town/city are more likely to be based on a range of factors including exposure to descriptive norms. As such, we expect that the descriptive norm condition will be particularly effective in shifting participants’ norm perception of people in their town/city. We will run secondary analyses related to perception of norms for close family and friends, but are uncertain if they will be affected by the descriptive norm manipulation. )

3. In general, there will be a positive association between participants’ self-report ratings of interdependent self-construal and their perceived social distancing norms of people in their town / city (for participants in the no message control condition). 

4. Participants’ self-report ratings of interdependent self-construal will moderate the relationship between experimental condition (norm/humor/autonomy vs. control) and their perceived social distancing norms of people in their town/city. Specifically, we expect to see stronger, positive effects of our experimental (vs. control) conditions on perceived norms for those low in interdependent self construal, since people high in interdependent self-construal will already show relatively higher perceived norms across conditions.

Analysis 11 concerns the type of normative messages:

11. All our descriptive norm messages were written using one of the following three pronouns: “I”, “we”, “most people”. For instance:
“I” message: Social distancing is critical for reducing exposure to #covid19.  I am staying home to stop hundreds of others from being infected.
“We” message: Social distancing is critical for reducing exposure to #covid19.  We are staying home to stop hundreds of others from being infected.
“Most people” message: Social distancing is critical for reducing exposure to #covid19.  Most people are staying home to stop hundreds of others from being infected.

We will investigate if different wording of descriptive norm messages (using either “I”, “we”, or “most people”) has an effect on participants’ ratings on message favorability, motivation, and relevance, compared to the control condition. This analysis will be conducted in participants in the descriptive norm and message control conditions, and this will be tested using multilevel models specified as below:

lmer(self motivation ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(other motivation ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(self relevance ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(social relevance   ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(message favorability ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))
lmer(sharing intention ~ message type +  age + (1 | participant) + (1 | message))

We will also explore how covariates (e.g. gender, interdependence self-construal, independence self-construal, SES, political orientation and partisanship etc.) affect the primary analyses. To do so, we will use specification curve analysis to assess the robustness of exploratory effects across different model specifications. We will collect an additional sample to replicate any findings identified using exploratory methods.

Variable definitions:
Self relevance: This message is relevant to me (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Self motivation: This message motivates me to avoid physical contact with others (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Other motivation: This message would motivate people I know to avoid physical contact with others (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Sharing intention: I would share this message on social media (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree).
Interdependence self construal (averaged):
Listed below are a number of statements. Read each one as if it referred to you.
In general, groups I belong to are an important part of my self-image. 
It is important for me to maintain harmony with my group.
I often have the feeling that my relationships with others are more important than my own accomplishments.
I feel good when I cooperate with others. 

Social distancing intentions (average):
Please rate how much you intend to do the following things over the next two weeks.
Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if I’m not sick. 
Limit my grocery shopping to once a week or less.
Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when I’m in public.
Avoid all public gatherings, even if I’m not sick.

Social distancing self beliefs (average).
If I stay home everyday for the next two weeks, and avoid social contact,  even if I’m not sick (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree):
I will avoid coming in contact with coronavirus. 
I will be less likely to get COVID-19.
I will be less likely to get sick.
I will keep myself safe. 
I will be able to take care of myself.

Social distancing others beliefs (average). 
If I stay home everyday for the next two weeks, and avoid social contact,  even if I’m not sick (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree):
I will keep my family safe. 
I will keep people in my community safe. 
I will prevent others from getting COVID-19.
I will protect more vulnerable people in our society.
I will slow the spread of COVID-19. 
It will be good for society.
It will help stop the spread of COVID-19.
It will help the healthcare system from being over flooded and enable people who need urgent medical care to receive it. 

Social distance norm beliefs (average)
If I stay home everyday for the next two weeks, and avoid social contact,  even if I’m not sick (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree):
It will be awkward to avoid my friends. (Reversed)
My friends will approve of my decision. 
My family will approve of my decision. 
People I work with will approve of my decision. 

Social distancing norms_close (average)
For these questions, think about your closest friends and family. What proportion of them… (0%-100%) 
Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if they aren’t sick. 
Limit their grocery shopping to once a week or less. 
Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when they’re in public. 
Avoid all public gatherings, even if they aren’t sick.
registration_responses.sample:
We conducted a small pilot study to assess potential effect sizes and variance parameters. Based on these results, we conducted a power analysis using the PANGEA power calculator (https://jakewestfall.shinyapps.io/pangea/) and determined we would have >80% power to detect an effect size of d = .2 for within- and between-subject effects with N = 200 per experimental condition.

As such, according to the sample size calculation, and assuming an exclusion rate of 10% (see exclusion criteria), we propose to recruit approximately 220 participants per condition.
registration_responses.analyses:
Since the analyses in this pre-registration are primarily focused on the effectiveness of descriptive norms, unless otherwise stated, analyses will be conducted in participants in descriptive norm and message control conditions only. Please see other pre-registrations in the same project (https://osf.io/8hn2g/) for analyses related to the autonomy and humor conditions. 

For each of the following analyses, we will first test if age is significantly associate with the respective DV. If so, age will be included as covariates in the model. 

1. Two mixed effect multilevel models will be constructed to investigate the favorability and social relevance ratings of messages in descriptive norm condition compared to control condition. The models will be specified as below, at the message x participant level:

md = lmer(message favorability ~ condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))
md = lmer(social relevance ~ condition + (1|participant ID) + (1|message ID))

We predict that there will be a positive fixed effect of condition (reference level: control) for both models, at significance level p < .05. 


2. A linear regression model will be constructed to compare perceived norms of participants in control vs. descriptive norm condition. The model will be specified as below:

md = lm(norm_town_socialdis ~ condition)

We predict that condition (reference level: control condition) will have a positive regression coefficient, significance level at p < .05. 


3. To test for a positive association between interdependence and perceived norm for participants in the no message condition, the following linear regression model will be constructed: 

md = lm(norm_town_socialdis ~ interdependence)

We predict that interdependence will have a positive regression coefficient, significance level at p < .05. The interdependence measure is defined in the Secondary Analysis section. 

4. A multiple linear regression model will be constructed to test the interaction effect between interdependence and condition. This analysis will be conducted in all participants across all message conditions (excluding participants in the no message control condition). A multiple regression model will be constructed as specified below: 

md = lm(norm_town_socialdis ~ condition * interdependence + condition + interdependence ) 

In this model, control condition will be set as reference level, with the experimental conditions (norm, autonomous and humor) will be treated as one level (experimental).
registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded according to the criteria in the standard operating procedures for this project listed on OSF: https://osf.io/8hn2g/.
registration_responses.dependent:
1. Perceived social norms (Measured at individual level; an average of the ratings to the following four questions will be used.)

For these questions, think about people in your city or town. What proportion of them… (0%-100%) 
Stay home and avoid all social contact, even if they aren’t sick.
Limit their grocery shopping to once a week or less.
Stay at least 6 feet apart from others when they’re in public. 
Avoid all public gatherings, even if they aren’t sick.

2. Message Social relevance (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree)

This message is relevant to other people I know. 

3. Message Favorability (1 = strongly disagree 7 = strongly agree; calculated by subtracting question 2 from question 1)

(1) The message put thoughts in my mind about wanting to avoid physical contact with others. 
(2) The message put thoughts in my mind about not wanting to avoid physical contact with others.
registration_responses.conditions:
Participants will be assigned to one of the following five conditions: descriptive norm, autonomy, humor, message control, or no message control condition (https://osf.io/8hn2g/). Each participant will see a series of 5 messages about covid19 randomly sampled from a pool of 15 messages in each condition (other than the no message control condition). Each message is created to look like an Instagram post that includes a visual message about covid-19 accompanied by a “post” about the message. Messages from experimental conditions (humor/norms/autonomy) and the message control condition have the same image, but the text accompanying the images were manipulated such that the control condition includes only a message about covid-19, where as 1) the descriptive norm condition includes the control message as well as information regarding the descriptive norm surrounding social distancing, 2) the humorous condition includes the control message as in addition to a humorous statement ridiculing behaviors which do not follow social distancing, and 3) the autonomous condition contains additional text framed using autonomous language. Participants in the no message control condition will not be exposed to any messages. 


Example from Control condition: Staying home protects our community by stopping the spread of #covid19.

Example from Descriptive norm condition: Staying home protects our community by stopping the of #covid19. Many people are staying home today to help each other in this pandemic.

Example from Humorous condition: Staying home helps stop the spread of #coronavirus. And yet some people will insist on NOT working from home. Why? Cause you miss passing by co-workers on the way to the bathroom?

Example from Autonomous condition: Staying home protects our community by stopping the spread of #covid19. Your choices have immense power to help others!
registration_responses.hypothesis:
1. Descriptive norm messages will be rated as more favorable and socially relevant compared to control messages. 

2. Compared to participants in the control condition, participants in the descriptive norm condition will show higher levels of perceived norms regarding social distancing behavior in people in their town/city. 

（Note: we also plan to measure perceived social distancing norms in close family and friends, which is listed as secondary analysis in the Other section. We expect that individuals’ norm perceptions of their close friends and family will be mainly based on direct social interactions. On the other hand, individuals’ norm perceptions of people in their town/city are more likely to be based on a range of factors including exposure to descriptive norms. As such, we expect that the descriptive norm condition will be particularly effective in shifting participants’ norm perception of people in their town/city. We will run secondary analyses related to perception of norms for close family and friends, but are uncertain if they will be affected by the descriptive norm manipulation. )

3. In general, there will be a positive association between participants’ self-report ratings of interdependent self-construal and their perceived social distancing norms of people in their town / city (for participants in the no message control condition). 

4. Participants’ self-report ratings of interdependent self-construal will moderate the relationship between experimental condition (norm/humor/autonomy vs. control) and their perceived social distancing norms of people in their town/city. Specifically, we expect to see stronger, positive effects of our experimental (vs. control) conditions on perceived norms for those low in interdependent self construal, since people high in interdependent self-construal will already show relatively higher perceived norms across conditions.

attributes.title: Influence of COVID-19 pandemic on misinformation susceptibility and problem solving
attributes.description:
While misinformation has been a feature of human experience for as long as people could formulate arguments, the rise of the internet and social media
has created conditions in which individuals or groups can create fake news capable of reaching millions of people in short order. Fast circulation of fake news has become particularly pernicious during the state of social panic created by the COVID-19 pandemic, where people are forced to make fast decisions and solve problems in a very short time. In this study we aim to understand how fear and the feeling of panic modulate believing in fake news, and investigate what reasoning abilities (specifically insight problem solving) might diminish
susceptibility to believing in misinformation. Previous research from our group has shown that performance of insight problem solving predicts differences in susceptibility to fake news, bullshit receptivity, and overclaiming. Yet, whether this relation holds during conditions of panic and fear remains unexplored.
Considering the quick spreading of the pandemic, we will run the study in American and Italian samples and compare cultural and temporal differences. To this aim we created a new set of fake news headlines related to COVID-19 and we will administer it to the two samples in the US and in Italy (where the pandemic has the highest number of people affected by COVID-19) together with a set of Rebus Puzzles, CRT problems, bullshit receptivity, xenophobia, COVID- 19 severity, and overclaiming scales. Our samples will be tested twice, during the COVID-19 pandemic and after, when the perceived threat of COVID-19 is mitigated.

q1.value: Carola Salvi, Alice Cancer, Paola Iannello, Mason McClay, Sabrina Rago, Joseph E. Dunsmoor, Alessandro Antonietti

q2.value:
Our primary hypotheses are:

1) Fear perception will make people less likely to distinguish fake news from real news.

2) Insightfulness will account for a significant amount of variance in believing in fake news (over and above traditional reasoning measures i.e., the CRT), sharing news content on the media, bullshit receptivity, and overclaiming accuracy. Specifically, insightfulness will positively predict ability to detect fake news.

3) These effects will differ between our during-pandemic samples and our post-pandemic samples. Specifically, post-pandemic samples will be better at detecting fake news compared to our during-pandemic samples.

These results will have an important implication for understanding situational and individual differences in susceptibility to false beliefs and more generally will allow us to shed light on what factors and reasoning abilities may contrast with believing in misinformation.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a within-subjects cross-sectional design across two cohorts of American and Italian samples.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via email. Participants must be between 18-80 years old and must either speak English or Italian.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 500 participants. We will attempt to recruit 800, assuming not all will complete the total task.

q13.value: We will continue distributing the questionnaire to potential participants until the stop of the first wave(s) of COVID-19 in our samples’ respective countries. We will resume data collection when COVID-19 has ceased spreading or during times of relative stability between waves of infections.

question.value: We will use the timepoints during and after COVID-19 Pandemic as naturalistic variables of manipulation.

Fake News Questionnaire: Each participant will be shown 12 news headlines. The headlines will be split in a 2x2 factor design by authenticity (fake or real story) and COVID-19 relevance (COVID-19-related or neutral story). Participants will be given 30 seconds to view and read the headline and indicate if they have seen the story before (yes, no, unsure), how accurate the headline is (Likert of 1-4; 1 = not at all accurate, 4 = very accurate), and whether they would share the story online (yes, no, maybe). 

Rebus Puzzles: Each participant will be shown 20 rebus puzzles. For each puzzle, they will be given 15 seconds to indicate whether or not they have a solution. If they select no or run out of time, they will be skipped to the next rebus. If they select yes, they will be taken to the next page where they will be instructed to enter their solution and indicate whether they solved the puzzle through insight (aha! moment) or analysis (step-by-step problem solving).

CRT: Each participant will be shown 4 cognitive reflection test (CRT) problems. The tests are self-paced mathematical problems. Participants provide their answers below the question in a text entry box.

Bullshit Scale (BS): Each participant will be presented with 20 profound pseudo-philosophical statements. They will rate how profound they believe the statement is on a Likert scale of 1 (not at all profound) to 5 (very profound). 

Overclaiming (OC): Each participant will be presented with 13 historical figures/events, some of which aren’t real. They will rate whether they have heard of the person/event from a  Likert scale of 1 (never heard of it) to 7 (very familiar). 

COVID-19 Fear Scale: Each participant will be asked to evaluate on a sliding scale of 0-100: the severity of COVID-19, how they would feel when they think about how serious it would be if they contracted COVID-19, how likely they are to get COVID-19, how they feel about the chance of getting infected, as well as to indicate on a Likert scale (1-7) how much they intend to search for information about COVID-19 or take action to reduce their chance of getting infected.

Xenophobia Scale (XS): Each participant will be presented with 14 items regarding immigration and will be asked how much they agree with each statement on a Likert scale of 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Ambiguity Scale (AS): Each participant will be presented with 30 items regarding ambiguous circumstances and will be asked how much they agree with each statement on a Likert scale of 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

1) We will perform a group comparison across the American and Italian samples for all the dependent variables using mixed model 2 (nationality)-by 2 (insight versus step-by-step problem solvers) ANOVA and t-tests. We will also perform a mixed model 2 (nationality)-by 2 (insight versus step-by-step problem solvers)-by 2 (during versus post-pandemic) ANOVA and t-tests.

2) For continuous variables we will perform multiple linear regression models, with fake news as our primary outcome variables, and rebus responses (accuracy, insight vs problem solving), OC score, BS score, XS, AS, COVID-19 Fear Scale, and time (during or post-pandemic) as our predictor variables. 

3) We will split our participants as either insight problem solvers or step-by-step problem solvers, and perform separate ANOVAs and regressions on each group.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons. In our multiple linear regressions, we will test for significant contribution to the variance of our outcome variables by comparing models in an additive fashion.

q20.value: Participants who do not complete the fake news questionnaire will be excluded from the analysis.

q21.value: If a participant does not complete the fake news questionnaire, they will be excluded from analysis.

q22.value: We expect that certain demographic and personality traits may be related to fake news susceptibility, problem solving, overclaiming, and feelings of the profound. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender, income, education, and nationality) and the primary outcome measures of fake news, problem solving, and overclaiming.

Specifically, insightfulness will positively predict ability to detect fake news.

3) These effects will differ between our during-pandemic samples and our post-pandemic samples. Specifically, post-pandemic samples will be better at detecting fake news compared to our during-pandemic samples.

These results will have an important implication for understanding situational and individual differences in susceptibility to false beliefs and more generally will allow us to shed light on what factors and reasoning abilities may contrast with believing in misinformation.

attributes.title: Distinct relationships between youth depression and within-network functional connectivity of the fronto-parietal and default mode networks
attributes.description: This project aims to examine the relationship between functional connectivity (FC) and youth depression both cross-sectionally and longitudinally, particularly with respect to the default mode network (DMN) and the frontoparietal network (FPN). The subjects consist of 124 youths aged between 6 and 13 who had available FC data at the first fMRI wave of data collection. I hypothesize that depressive symptoms will be negatively associated with FC during rest within the FPN and positively associated FC during rest within the DMN at the first fMRI assessment wave of the Preschool Depression Study (PDS). I will also conduct exploratory analyses upon the effects of inter-network FC on baseline depression at the first fMRI wave of data collection, and the relationship between the trajectory of depressive symptoms at four follow-up assessments and baseline symptoms.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Distinct relationships between youth depression and within-network functional connectivity of the fronto-parietal and default mode networks

other.value: Exploratory analyses will examine associations between individual trajectories of depressive symptoms (i.e. slopes) using hierarchical linear modeling. We may subsequently examine the interaction between slope (change in depressive symptoms) and intercept (depressive symptoms at the first fMRI wave). We may also measure whether inter-network functional connectivity of the frontoparietal and default mode networks is associated with depressive symptoms at the first fMRI wave. These analyses are exploratory because few prior studies have tested these associations. Therefore, I do not have a specific hypothesis about the directions of these relationships. Psychotropic medication use will be included as an additional covariate in follow-up analyses. It will not be used in initial analyses due to concerns that it would overcorrect for participants experiencing severe levels of depression, who are more likely to be using psychotropic medications to manage their symptoms.

sample.value: N=124 youth, ages 6-13 years old, had FC data at the first fMRI wave of data collection.

analyses.value: Multiple regressions will be used to measure associations between functional connectivity within-each network and depression, while controlling for age, gender, race and income-to-need ratio, as covariates. False discovery rate (FDR) multiple comparison correction will be used for all analyses.

outliers.value: Participants with less than 5 minutes of usable resting state fMRI data will be excluded from planned analyses. Mahalanobis distance between each within-network functional connectivity metric and children’s depression inventory score will be calculated and used to exclude multivariate outliers with a threshold of p<0.001.

dependent.value:
Functional connectivity during rest will be quantified by temporal correlation of BOLD signal activities within the FPN network and DMN network, separately. Data from the first fMRI wave of functional connectivity data collection from the PDS will be used for all analyses. Networks are defined by the parcellation from Power et al. (2011). 
Children’s Depression Inventory (CDI) Total Raw Scores reported by the participant and one of their parents will be averaged and the percentage calculated (out of a total maximum score of 56) to quantify the severity of depression. Higher % CDI scores indicate greater depressive symptoms, while lower % CDI scores indicate fewer depressive symptoms. 
CDI raw scores from 4 subsequent waves will be used for exploratory analyses. In the fifth wave of fMRI (FC) data collection, the Beck Depression Inventory 2 (BDI-2) was collected on some participants instead of the CDI, when participants were 18 years old or older. Therefore, a percentage of raw score out of total score will also be calculated for each participant that completed the BDI-2, in order to make their scores comparable to those that completed the CDI.

conditions.value: Participants will not be assigned to groups since this study is correlational.

hypothesis.value: I predict that depressive symptoms will be negatively associated with functional connectivity (FC) during rest within the frontoparietal network (FPN) and positively associated with functional connectivity during rest within the default mode network (DMN) at the first fMRI assessment wave of the Preschool Depression Study (PDS).

attributes.title: Fostering prosocial responses to the COVID-19 pandemic
attributes.description: How do we unite against a common threat such as COVID-19? How can we harness the collective (“we”) instead of the individual (“I”), in curbing its spread? As the pandemic unfolds, some people might mitigate the negative situation by cooperating by default (Drury, Cocking & Reicher, 2009). However, others might be more inclined to act in a more individualistic way (e.g., panic buying) instead of more collectively (e.g., buying enough for themselves and preserving more for others). In the current pandemic, the general advice is that people need to (1) act not only to protect themselves, but also the most vulnerable and (2) do something counterintuitive: protect the more vulnerable by increasing the physical distance to them, when in fact decreasing social distance is a natural tendency in cooperation (Klein, 2020). How can we overcome the ‘individualistic’ impulse and adopt counter-intuitive behaviour? In three studies, we will test three methods that can improve the public’s response to the current pandemic, based on social identity theories and individual differences that tell us who is more and less likely to follow recommendations (e.g., trust, political ideology, conspiracy mentality, individualism, susceptibility to the virus).

attributes.title: Status Seeking and Public Discourse Ethics: A Nationally Representative Sample with Longitudinal Follow-up
attributes.description: This project (sponsored by the Charles Koch Foundation) is an examination of the role of status-seeking motives and drives in influencing political polarization and public discourse. The first wave of this work (N = 2,519) was collected via YouGov in August of 2019. Follow-up waves are scheduled every six months until August 2021.
